publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 92.50

seg.seg: out of compassion. When ... come to you ...
if he asks you, then you shall say the following to this: from the desire
Wenn sie euch fragen, dann sagt ihnen dies:
If they ask you, tell them this:
... Then the Buddha spoke the strophe in the assembly ...
(whose) spirit [is] always (unrestrained) here, one whose (course) is directed upwards [he will] (be called)
and a monk [that had/has been] living/staying in the Jetavana earlier
(the law). [Even] I [myself] would like to grasp only in brief, directed at the one goal ..
That which [is] coarse here: gravel, dirt or stones ...
the good (deeds) in (mind), body and words ...
for, if like gold [is] your mind, without ...
shall (blow away?) the dirt of the (own) self. This the (man) grasped ...
(to his own (?) best). There first step by step (in the Kausala-countries) ...
delivered from all such sufferings. To him the Buddha spoke ...
the haze [has been] driven away by me, therefore I now sit ...
the one having the (ten) powers ... he heard the law [and] obtained ...

p.note: Kāmavarga (II), part 1. Due to the loss of two thirds of the leaf as well as all strophe numbering, the coherence of the text has suffered badly and so has the translation’s. The metre is 4x13 + 21 syllables in a 5/8 and 8/8/5 rhythm, but it is impossible to define individual verses with any certainty.

The original manuscript is missing, but was the left hand side of leaf 30 to the schnurloch. About 3/4 of the leaf (of ca. 40 syllables) were missing for each line. The script was severely attrited in some places.

div.head: Sanskrit parallel
div.p: corresponds to Uv. II, 9: chanda jāto hy avasrāvī manasānāvilo bhavet kāmeṣu tv apratibaddha citta ūrdhva sroto nirucyate
Of the man in whom the aspiration (for Nirvana) is born, who has escaped impurity, whose mind is calm, whose thought is not attached to desire, it is said: He is above the stream.
corresponds to Uv. II, 10: anupūrveṇa medhāvī stokaṃ stokaṃ kṣaṇe kṣaṇe karmāro rajatasyaiva nirdhamen malaṃ ātmanaḥ
Gradually, little by little, tirelessly, the wise man should cast out the defilement in himself, like the workman that in silver.

list.item: The original manuscript is missing, but was the left hand side of leaf 30 to the schnurloch. About 3/4 of the leaf (of ca. 40 syllables) were missing for each line. The script was severely attrited in some places.

Alternative classifications:
Peyrot–
Malzahn–
TamaiII-3 (800-900)
Tamai-C14–

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]

a2 Wenn sie euch fragen, dann sagt ihnen dies: 54

Sanskrit parallel

a4. corresponds to Uv. II, 9:
chanda jāto hy avasrāvī manasānāvilo bhavet
kāmeṣu tv apratibaddha citta ūrdhva sroto nirucyate


Of the man in whom the aspiration (for Nirvana) is born, who has escaped impurity, whose mind is calm, whose thought is not attached to desire, it is said: He is above the stream.


b2. corresponds to Uv. II, 10:
anupūrveṇa medhāvī stokaṃ stokaṃ kṣaṇe kṣaṇe
karmāro rajatasyaiva nirdhamen malaṃ ātmanaḥ


Gradually, little by little, tirelessly, the wise man should cast out the defilement in himself, like the workman that in silver.

a1 out of compassion. When ... come to you ... a2 if he asks you, then you shall say the following to this: from the desire a3 ... Then the Buddha spoke the strophe in the assembly ... a4 (whose) spirit [is] always (unrestrained) here, one whose (course) is directed upwards [he will] (be called) a5 and a monk [that had/has been] living/staying in the Jetavana earlier a6 (the law). [Even] I [myself] would like to grasp only in brief, directed at the one goal .. a7 That which [is] coarse here: gravel, dirt or stones ... a8 the good (deeds) in (mind), body and words ... b1 for, if like gold [is] your mind, without ... b2 shall (blow away?) the dirt of the (own) self. This the (man) grasped ... b3 (to his own (?) best). There first step by step (in the Kausala-countries) ... b4 ... came at that time ... b5 ... (such) sufferings [of his] self ... b6 delivered from all such sufferings. To him the Buddha spoke ... b7 the haze [has been] driven away by me, therefore I now sit ... b8 the one having the (ten) powers ... he heard the law [and] obtained ...

General remarks

Kāmavarga (II), part 1. Due to the loss of two thirds of the leaf as well as all strophe numbering, the coherence of the text has suffered badly and so has the translation’s. The metre is 4x13 + 21 syllables in a 5/8 and 8/8/5 rhythm, but it is impossible to define individual verses with any certainty.
